I came to this restaurant because a friend recommended the crema catalan here; and he was correct, it was really delicious.  I had trepidation about getting dinner because reviews on this site, and others, were very split.-yes: stale bread will be put on your table and you will be charged for it-yes: the service left much to be desired, with the grumpy waiter disappearing for great lengths of time.-yes: the paella was WAY too salty.  I really did not care for it at all.  I would rate them worse, but it may just be that my American pallet isn't tuned into this dish.  That said, I've had paella in Andalusia that blew my mind.**[**post-script: I was describing this experience to fellow travelers at a bar.  Some nearby, possibly biased, Spaniards overheard me and instructed, "No!  You should NEVER order paella in the North.  They don't know what they're doing.  Blech!"]The other reason I don't rate this place lower is because it was filled with locals.  Haha, none of them were ordering paella.  So, if you do end up going here, I recommend bypassing the "house dish".  Or, just come here for dessert.  That said, I suspect this is one of those places that exists because it's a tradition for a lot of families, so it gets "institution status".  Honestly, aside from the questionable pintxos bar I drunkenly stumbled into one night, this was the only meal I did not enjoy my entire time in Spain.
